p: The monoterpene hydrocarbons and oxygenated monoterpenes in the essential oil of different plants possess major antimicrobial, antifungal, and antiviral activities [ 34]. Our results indicating antibacterial activity against E. coli and P. aeruginosa are concurrent with those of other studies [ 20, 21]. The cardamom oil was probably active against P. aeruginosa and E. coli due to the presence of 1,8 cineole and α-terpinyl acetate, which is supported by several investigations [ 13, 34]. Time-kill kinetic studies indicated that essential oil of E. cardamomum exhibits bacteriostatic activities against P. aeruginosa and E. coli, which may be due to the presence of 1,8 cineole, α-terpinyl acetate, and other active antimicrobial volatile agents [ 35, 36, 37].
